title: Thursday, 18th October 2018

We believe that to live well in an age when everything moves at breakneck speed, we need to take the time to investigate what’s really going on, to make sense of the forces shaping our future.
We are a different kind of newsroom. Not breaking news, but what’s driving the news. Not the news as it happens, but when it’s ready.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

It also eases some of the concerns about Domino's pissing off its franchisees.

BE11:14am

Here's Numis.

BE11:14am

3Q UK LFL +2.2% (+3.6% ticket, -1.4% volume) is ahead of our forecast (+0.5%), an expected deceleration vs. 4.7% in Q2, reflecting the unprecedented hot weather in Jul/Aug, compounded by the challenging comparator (+8.1%). Two-year cumulative LFL growth of 10.3% continues its double-digit growth track record. DOM opened 20 stores in 3Q, an expected but very welcome acceleration from the 22 stores opened in 1H and leaves it on track to meet its 60 target for FY18. This drove UK system sales of £277m (NSe £280m), +6.1% yoy. Store openings (42 ytd from 28 different franchisees) should challenge some bearish commentators that have suggested that the franchisees are unwilling to open new stores.

CRH PLC (CRH:LSE): Last: 2,218, down 99 (-4.27%), High: 2,248, Low: 2,183, Volume: 2.22m
hedgehog are the Johnston bonds listed ?
11:25 am
BE11:25am

Cazenove's cautious going into results ......

BE11:25am

We expect Q3-2018 to be another lackluster quarter for the European Building Materials sector with consensus expectations likely to be revised down yet again. However, valuation is already reflecting this in our view as the sector is down 23% YTD and has underperformed the market by 17%. We would position for stocks where we believe that the required growth rate for H2 is achievable, i.e., CRH and SGO. We continue to see downside risk to HEI’s guidance (and 2019 consensus) but this is somewhat reflected in valuation. LHN continues to look vulnerable on valuation, although comps get easier in Q4. We remain cautious on near term earnings risks at TKTT and BZU despite the significant discount on valuation.

BE11:26am

Tactical stock positioning into results. Despite increasing cost inflation we think H2 expectations are achievable at SGO and think Q3 results could reassure a bearish investor positioning. US peers reporting might first look negative for CRH which doesn't report until Nov 20, but we remain confident the group can achieve H2 expectations despite the weather disruptions. Although we acknowledge the valuation discount at HEI, we continue to see risks to consensus estimates and cut our FY EBITDA forecast by a further 1%; we think Management could cut guidance as well. LHN valuation remains more demanding, but note comps get easier in Q4, therefore we see less downside risks to estimates near term. We remain cautious on near term earnings risks at TKTT and BZU (we cut our FY estimate by 2% at BZU).

irish hedge fund guy @Dec69 Skeptic, hard to short bonds outside of CDS. CDS market is highly manipulable. Would seem that £100m for the whole of JPR seems reasonable. There must be some rich Scots person who wishes own the Scotsman. Perhaps a Wealthly female so it can be renamed
BE11:30am

HeidelbergCement has released a profit warning, cutting FY18 organic EBITDA growth guidance from a “mid to high single digit” percentage increase to a “low to mid single percentage decrease”. This implies a 5% cut to consensus forecasts for FY18 and c.7% to Goodbody forecasts. This will bring the cumulative cut to forecasts to 15% in the year to date. Net debt/EBITDA will now be above the previous guidance of 2.5x. Management notes that the cut to guidance is due to adverse weather in the US and higher than anticipated energy costs. Nonetheless, share of profit for the year is expected to be in line with consensus suggesting gains on interest, tax and other below the line items.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

And UBS.

Excel Developer oh my comment filter is working. Some people in today are being screened out. Splendid.
BE11:31am

Cutting FY18 EBITDA guidance to low to mid-single digit LFL decline
HeidelbergCement, not entirely unexpectedly, is cutting FY18 EBITDA guidance to a low to mid-single digit LFL EBITDA decline (previous guidance was for mid to high-single digit growth). We had expected a cut and forecast +1% LFL growth, but we think property gains will likely be lower than we modelled, which could easily account for ~€100m shortfall or ~3%. We think new guidance implies €2.97bn to €3.06bn EBITDA (UBSE €3.157/cons €3.2 – incl. €200m of property gains, flat y/y). However, EPS is anticipated to be in line with consensus estimates of €6.39 (UBSE €6.02), although it's unclear what compensates for weaker EBITDA. Net debt/EBITDA will be above 2.5x (UBSE 2.6x) and we think it's likely to be around 2.8x.

Cost inflation, weather in the US
The culprits are generally higher energy cost inflation and adverse weather conditions in the US – these issues are not entirely unexpected but the impact is modestly higher than expected. There is not much granularity for Q3 at this stage, which will be reported on the 8th November.

What is the support level?
In our recent note we saw a downside valuation of €55 per share which assumes EBITDA decline for 2018 and 2019 and de-rating to 7x. While we expect shares to be soft initially, realistic guidance is more helpful in the valuation argument. On our forecasts, the shares trade on over 10% 2019E EFCF yield – even if that FCF end up being somewhat lower, we think that's attractive.

Valuation: Buy, €81 price target
Our PT is based on DCF with WACC of 8% and long-term EBIT margin of 12.5%

Rural Economy Secretary, Fergus Ewing, said: “Following confirmation of a case of classical BSE in Aberdeenshire, I have activated the Scottish Government’s response plan to protect our valuable farming industry, including establishing a precautionary movement ban being placed on the farm

“While it is important to stress that this is standard procedure until we have a clear understanding of the disease’s origin, this is further proof that our surveillance system for detecting this type of disease is working.

“Be assured that the Scottish Government and its partners stand ready to respond to any further confirmed cases of the disease in Scotland.”

Adjusting for the ongoing impact from last September’s
hurricane in Puerto Rico the rate of organic revenue growth was 4.4%, an improvement of 1.0% over 1H’s 3.4%. The factors behind the acceleration included favourable, compared to adverse, weather conditions and an improvement in the rate of decline in UK Property Care. The mix shift within the portfolio towards the higher growth/higher margin pest control activities continues

The shares trade on 22.7x 2019E EPS and 12.9x 2019E EBITDA, in aggregate a 91% premium to the FTSE All Share. However, US peer Rollins trades on substantially higher multiples, 47.0x 2019E P/E. Rentokil’s high margin, stable growth pest control activities are becoming a greater proportion ofthe portfolio (63% of group revenues and 68% of group EBITA), which should be further enhanced by M&A.

TonaldDrump any organic growth or just acquisition? @BE

On the rollups, the CMA has coincidentally put out its report today on Rentokil's purchase of Cannon Hygiene’s UK ops.

11:50 am

BE11:51am

Here's Jefferies.

BE11:51am

The CMA will seek comments up to November 1 regarding their remedies notice, which could include the potential sale of Cannon UK if the findings conclude that there has been a substantial lessening of competition. Cannon UK is £15M of revenue and £1M of profits, thus we believe this decision will have a negligible impact on consensus estimates. That being said, we believe this could provide a negative read-across regarding sentiment and uncertainty regarding Rentokil's recent acquisition of Mitie Pest Control.

Grouchmonkey @Mouselet agreed - not saying it was ethical, at all
11:52 am
BE11:52am

While we commend the accomplishments of management, we downgraded Rentokil to Hold in July, based on 1) Valuation. Rentokil currently trades at 25x FY18 adj. EPS, versus its trading range of 7 – 28x. 2) We believe Balance Sheet capacity provides little upside risk to consensus (JEFe FY18 2.2x ND/EBITDA). 3) An opaque path to margin progression, with near-term M&A and above-the-line investment offsetting density benefits from increased scale.
